pages.text: Procompsognathus, despite its name, is not actually a compsognathid, but rather a coelophysid. It is known from the Triassic of Germany and was quite small, at only around 1 meter in length. The taxonomic history of this animal is complex. Originally regarded as a species of Hallopus, it was eventually named Procompsognathus under the assumption that it was the direct ancestor to the Jurassic Compsognathus.

However, this was not supported by further research, and it has since landed closer to Coelophysis. Like other coelophysids, this dinosaur was likely a hunter, though, due to its size, it probably hunted much smaller animals like insects and early squamates. Procompsognathus is also thought to be a good runner on account of a proportionally lengthened tibia as compared to its relatives.
